title: Is it true that when you continue charging your phone after 100% that it will damage the battery? - Quora

response.answer_text: The charger is inside the phone, the thing you plug in is a supply of charging power - a power supply. The charger shuts off at 100%. If the battery drops by 1% or 2% (depending on the phone), the charger will “kick in” and bring it back to 100% - then shut off. Will it damage anything? Lithium batteries of the type used in cellphones (there are different types) last longest if they’re kept between about 80% and 40%, so charging to 100% will shorten the battery longevity, but not by enough to worry about, unless you plan on keeping the phone for 5 years or more. About the only possibility of damage is if a component in the charging circuit goes bad and, due to the fact that the “charger” is plugged in, starts a fire. So if you have a Note 7, get another phone. Otherwise, I wouldn’t worry about it. (I do “worry” about it in my phone, to the extent that, since I root all my phones anyway [how can you run Linux if you can’t get elevation to root when you need it - it’s like someone with an amputated right arm pitching right-handed], I run Magisk Charging Switch, set to 80 40 - if the phone drops down to 40%, and the “charger” is still connected, start charging. If the charge reaches 80%, stop charging. But before Magisk? I used to leave the charger plugged in for days at a time. And I recently sent that phone to a lady who [most likely] had hers stolen. It has a new battery in it - well, new about a year ago - but it was over 4 years old, and the batteries they put into phones these days can’t be expected to give like-new performance any longer than that. Never had a problem, except that the “charger” does draw a bit of current even when the charger in the phone shuts off, so if I had unplugged it at 80% for 5 years, I could probably have saved about a dollar or two by this time.)

The charger is not charging the phone when the battery is fully charged. Instead what it’s doing is powering the phone. The battery is effectively out of the circuit apart from the charge being monitored. So no, you can leave the phone connected to the charger as long as you like, and quite the opposite of doing any damage it’s prolonging the life of the battery by not using it to run the phone. Note however that the battery continues to self-discharge gradually. The phone monitors this and once the battery has discharged itself enough then the phone will connect the charger to it for a minute or so to restore full charge again. This may or may not show up on the charge percentage reported by the phone. There’s nothing you can do to prevent self-discharge, and unfortunately it means that the battery life gradually gets used even when the charger is attached. Just to be clear, the idea of keeping a battery at a partial charge being better for the battery than a full charge only works for storage, ie: when the phone is switched off. If the phone is on, even in standby, then it’s impossible to maintain a partial charge without cyclically connecting and disconnecting the charger, which means that the battery is powering the phone when the charger is disconnected. Powering the phone shortens the battery life more than being idle at full charge. In theory it would be possible for a phone manufacturer to offer a “maintain partial battery charge” option whilst the phone is plugged into a charger, instead of the “charge to full and then maintain full charge” approach used in today’s phones. This would also be ideal for long term storage of mobile devices, leaving a charger connected to ensure the battery doesn’t go completely flat. But of course this option doesn’t exist, and as it’s not really in the manufacturer’s interest to extend phone battery life then I can’t see the option being introduced.
